awd_titl_txt: Phylogeography and Population Genetics of the Central       American Howler Monkeys (Genus Alouatta)
awd_abstract_narration: This research project examines the evolutionary genetics of a group of New World primates.  The goals of the study include a reconstruction of the ancient invasion of Central America by howler monkeys and, as a secondary objective, a genetic analysis of social structure in a well-studied population of mantled howlers.  These objectives will be accomplished by comparing the genetic similarities between pairs of populations and pairs of individuals, respectively, using a DNA fingerprinting technology we developed specifically for these species.   This study will significantly augment our understanding of primate evolution in two ways.  First, we will provide a preliminary model for the population genetics of Central American primates in general, thus, providing a useful contrast with better known primate systems from Africa and Asia.  Second, the information generated by this study about New World primate genetics will provide basic information that can lay the foundation for future ecological and evolutionary studies in this group.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences
